We print in another column a summary of the lacrosse season that has
just ended. Unfortunate as the end
was, we are nevertheless not to feel
pessimistic nor even unduly disappointed at the outcome. Even in lacrosse, and certainly in other sports,
the closing one has been a good year
for Hopkins athletes. Our football
team made a wonderful record and
the games were exceptionally well attended. Both track and lacrosse
have done well and have furnished
assurance of better things for the future. Interest and support, too, from
the siulents have abounded and must
continue to abound. We shall do
wonders in the future with more of
the spirit that reached high tide last
November and swept over Homewood rield to overwhelm St. John's
We must have more of it for next
year, and the lacrosse team, the track
team, and that new baseball team
must share in it equally with the team
that is to win again from the "soldier
boys'." An indication of what was

accomplished this year and of the
i.ossibilities of the future is the announcement that every team turned
over a larger sum to the Athletic
Association than ever before. More
nioney means bigger things to come,
—better teams, larger crowds, new
grandstands, and more elaborate
Lchedules with bigger opponents. The
tecord is a compliment to the men
who have worked as hard as the
players and without the applause of
the managers. To them
the crowd
as %veil as their teams the credit be-

Baltimore, Md., May 19, 1910.
Editor of The News-Letter,
the
To
Johns Hopkins University, City
Dear Sir:
I note that The News-Letter has
drifted into the use of a bit of
phraseology, which, though quite
common with the daily newspapers,
is, in spite of this weight of philological authority, somewhat objectionable. I refer to your issue of
May t6th, in which the account of
the Virginia-Hopkins track meet is
hearled "Hopkins Humbled by Old
Ri 'al"
It is perhaps hypercritical to call
th:L, language unsportsmanlike, but,
after all, no one who has the love
of ti ue sport in his heart ever feels
that a deleated team is "humbled."
The use of the verb "to humble"
in this connection is inaccurate in
every way, except in so far as it
may mean "to reduce the exultation
of." This, one can readily admit, is
a necessary corrolary of defeat. It
is, however, quite contrary to the ethics of sport to state that a team is
"humiliated," "abased in pride or arrogance," or "made meek and submissive" by defeat. Such an attitude
of moral dejection should be reserved
solely for the sins of sportsmanship.
There is nothing finer in the day's
journey than to stop occasionally by
the roadway to see two bodies of
men, engaged against each other in
an athletic contest, and using all the
muscle, brain power, courage and determination that is in them, provided the whole affair is predominated
by a spirit of absolute fair play. To
say that when a little extra weight,
or burst of speed, or luck of the game
turns a victory for one side, that the
other side is thereby "humbled"shows
a lack of appreciation of the Olympian atmosphere.
I trust that for the sake of one
"constant reader'' a more descriptive
term may be found for future occa-

April 27, 1910.
The Editors, "News-Letter,"
Johns Hopkins University,
Baltimore, Maryland, U. S A.
Dear Sirs:
Since our letter to you of the
20th, we are happy to inform you
that we have made still further progress in that Colonel Roosevelt and
President Hadley of Yale have accepted honorary membership in our
club.
We are making arrangements, and
hope to have the honour of entertaming Colonel Roosevelt during his
stay in London, if his time will permit.
Very truly yours,
Geo. G. Knowles,
Vale, .92,
Chairman of Committee.
P. S.—President Lowell of Harvard has also accepted honorary
membership.

TOURNAMENT TODAY
Play Starts This Afternoon in
Annual Tennis Contest—Drawings For Opponents — Sophomore Team Chosen.
The first round of the annual Hopkins tennis tournament Will be
played this afternoon at Homewood,
and matches will be played daily until the tournament is over. Ed Clary
was the favorite in the singles, but
unfortunately he will be unable to
play on account of his broken collar
bone. Great interest is being taken
in the tournament this year and the
entry list has broken all records.
John G. Huck, the winner of last
years's freshman tournament, is expected to make a strong bid for first
place in the singles. First and secmid and a consolation prize will be
given. Many of the freshmen have
entered this year.

We print in another column a summary of the lacrosse season that has
just ended. Unfortunate as the end
was, we are nevertheless not to feel
pessimistic nor even unduly disappointed at the outcome. Even in lacrosse, and certainly in other sports,
the closing one has been a good year
for Hopkins athletes. Our football
team made a wonderful record and
the games were exceptionally well attended. Both track and lacrosse
have done well and have furnished
assurance of better things for the future. Interest and support, too, from
the siulents have abounded and must
continue to abound. We shall do
wonders in the future with more of
the spirit that reached high tide last
November and swept over Homewood rield to overwhelm St. John's
We must have more of it for next
year, and the lacrosse team, the track
team, and that new baseball team
must share in it equally with the team
that is to win again from the "soldier
boys'." An indication of what was

accomplished this year and of the
i.ossibilities of the future is the announcement that every team turned
over a larger sum to the Athletic
Association than ever before. More
nioney means bigger things to come,
—better teams, larger crowds, new
grandstands, and more elaborate
Lchedules with bigger opponents. The
tecord is a compliment to the men
who have worked as hard as the
players and without the applause of
the managers. To them
the crowd
as %veil as their teams the credit be-

Baltimore, Md., May 19, 1910.
Editor of The News-Letter,
the
To
Johns Hopkins University, City
Dear Sir:
I note that The News-Letter has
drifted into the use of a bit of
phraseology, which, though quite
common with the daily newspapers,
is, in spite of this weight of philological authority, somewhat objectionable. I refer to your issue of
May t6th, in which the account of
the Virginia-Hopkins track meet is
hearled "Hopkins Humbled by Old
Ri 'al"
It is perhaps hypercritical to call
th:L, language unsportsmanlike, but,
after all, no one who has the love
of ti ue sport in his heart ever feels
that a deleated team is "humbled."
The use of the verb "to humble"
in this connection is inaccurate in
every way, except in so far as it
may mean "to reduce the exultation
of." This, one can readily admit, is
a necessary corrolary of defeat. It
is, however, quite contrary to the ethics of sport to state that a team is
"humiliated," "abased in pride or arrogance," or "made meek and submissive" by defeat. Such an attitude
of moral dejection should be reserved
solely for the sins of sportsmanship.
There is nothing finer in the day's
journey than to stop occasionally by
the roadway to see two bodies of
men, engaged against each other in
an athletic contest, and using all the
muscle, brain power, courage and determination that is in them, provided the whole affair is predominated
by a spirit of absolute fair play. To
say that when a little extra weight,
or burst of speed, or luck of the game
turns a victory for one side, that the
other side is thereby "humbled"shows
a lack of appreciation of the Olympian atmosphere.
I trust that for the sake of one
"constant reader'' a more descriptive
term may be found for future occa-

The Editors, "News-Letter,"
Johns Hopkins University,
Baltimore, Maryland, U. S A.
Dear Sirs:
Since our letter to you of the
20th, we are happy to inform you
that we have made still further progress in that Colonel Roosevelt and
President Hadley of Yale have accepted honorary membership in our
club.
We are making arrangements, and
hope to have the honour of entertaming Colonel Roosevelt during his
stay in London, if his time will permit.
Very truly yours,
Geo. G. Knowles,
Vale, .92,
Chairman of Committee.
P. S.—President Lowell of Harvard has also accepted honorary
membership.

TOURNAMENT TODAY
Play Starts This Afternoon in
Annual Tennis Contest—Drawings For Opponents — Sophomore Team Chosen.
The first round of the annual Hopkins tennis tournament Will be
played this afternoon at Homewood,
and matches will be played daily until the tournament is over. Ed Clary
was the favorite in the singles, but
unfortunately he will be unable to
play on account of his broken collar
bone. Great interest is being taken
in the tournament this year and the
entry list has broken all records.
John G. Huck, the winner of last
years's freshman tournament, is expected to make a strong bid for first
place in the singles. First and secmid and a consolation prize will be

entered this year.
